repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Development Support Credit
            Series (I-IV) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First and Third
            Development Support Credit (DSC) Project for Bangladesh were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Second Development Support
            Credit Project were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Fourth Development Support Credit Project were as
            follows: outcomes were highly satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the Bank must
            maintain a close dialogue with political parties out of
            power and with other key opinion makers to have a better
            assessment of the support for reforms. This approach is
            strategic and must be done even while working closely with
            and supporting like minded governments. Such an approach
            helps to mitigate risks of possible reversals if and when
            the ruling parties change, and to avoid the appearance of
            playing favorites. The Bank needs to do much more targeted
            and tailored engagement and communication with stakeholders,
            quite apart from the Government. This is needed for
            deepening ownership and support for reforms under
            programmatic loans, such as the DSC. Such an approach
            becomes all the more critical during the tenure of an
            elected government which tends to be disproportionately
            sensitive to public opinion and is, oftentimes, reluctant to
            make unpopular policy choices.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Development Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings indicate a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, with modest institutional
            development impacts. This Simplified Implementation
            Completion Report (SICR) provides the following findings and
            implications for subsequent operation(s). The project sought
            to continue supporting Government's efforts to
            stabilize the macroeconomic environment, improve the
            investment climate, and strengthen economic institutions.
            While progress continued in each of these areas, on the
            institutional front, notable achievements included the
            establishment of the Energy Regulatory Commission, and the
            Anti-Corruption Commission, with some progress in
            strengthening tax administration and banking sector
            regulation by the Bangladesh Bank. However, these can only
            be viewed as incremental steps in what is necessarily a
            long-term and complex process of institutional building.
            Future operations need to be realistic in setting goals in
            this area; since local capacity is very weak, therefore, the
            Bank and the donor community will need to stay engaged,
            providing support over a long period. Project experience
            confirms that strong country ownership is essential for the
            success of reforms, best when the designs of these are
            homegrown. The reform process in the banking sector, for
            example, progressed slower than initially anticipated, due
            to inadequate attention given to the political economy,
            considerations which led to setting some over-ambitious
            goals. The political difficulty of implementing energy price
            increases was seemingly, also underestimated in designing
            the reforms. Also important, are future adjustment
            operations, which should be more closely aligned to the
            budget. In this regard, the Bank team is working with the
            Ministry of Finance to enhance the policy orientation of the
            budget, through the development of a medium-term budget framework.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Second Development Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The review suggests that overall
            progress with development support credit (DSC II) triggers
            has been positive. The macroeconomic framework is on track,
            banking and state own enterprise (SOE) reforms have
            proceeded with some minor variations and broad governance
            reforms have moved ahead. In the energy sector several
            structural reforms have moved ahead, although progress on
            the privatization front has been inadequate. The other area
            where there has been significant shortfall is regarding
            implementation of energy price agreements under DSC I. This
            is largely due to unanticipated surge in world oil prices
            and the Government considers a full pass through of these
            increases to consumers as politically impossible. It has
            nevertheless made some minimum adjustments in gas, kerosene
            and petrol prices and has also reduced the taxes on
            petroleum products. While all energy product prices
            excluding domestic taxes exceed international prices,
            including tax (weighted average rate of about 30%) the
            domestic prices fall short for kerosene and diesel. Since
            these products account for some 75% of total oil
            consumption, the Bangladesh Petroleum Corporation is
            incurring losses. The resultant adverse impact o f higher
            petroleum costs on BPC's finances has been offset by
            the lower central Government deficit. Importantly, the
            Government has taken new measures relating to tax revenues
            and trade tariff reductions in the FY05 budget that
            strengthen the overall reform program and demonstrate the
            Government's resolve to stay the course on reforms.
